content.question:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

<math alttext="P b I 2, solid, is in equilibrium with, P b with a positive 2 charge, aqueous, plus 2 I with a negative 1 charge, aqueous, K sub s p equals, 7 times 10 to the negative 9 power."><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PbI</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>⇄</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Pb</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="3.0em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>

The dissolution of <math alttext="P b I 2, solid"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PbI</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is represented above.

(a) A saturated solution is prepared by dissolving <math alttext="P b I 2, solid"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PbI</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in distilled water until no more solid dissolves. Write a mathematical expression that can be used to determine the value of <math alttext="S"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the molar solubility of <math alttext="P b I 2, solid"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PbI</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. (Do not do any numerical calculations.)

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

<math alttext="P b I 2, solid, is in equilibrium with, P b with a positive 2 charge, aqueous, plus 2 I with a negative 1 charge, aqueous, K sub s p equals, 7 times 10 to the negative 9 power."><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PbI</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>⇄</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Pb</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="3.0em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>

The dissolution of <math alttext="P b I 2, solid"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PbI</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is represented above.

(a) A saturated solution is prepared by dissolving <math alttext="P b I 2, solid"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PbI</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in distilled water until no more solid dissolves. Write a mathematical expression that can be used to determine the value of <math alttext="S"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the molar solubility of <math alttext="P b I 2, solid"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PbI</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. (Do not do any numerical calculations.)

(b) If <math alttext="P b I 2, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PbI</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is dissolved in <math alttext="1.0 molar of N a I, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>NaI</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, is the maximum possible concentration of <math alttext="P b with a positive 2 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Pb</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the solution greater than, less than, or equal to the concentration of <math alttext="P b with a positive 2 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Pb</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the solution in part (<math alttext="a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>a</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>)? Explain.

Compound<math alttext="K sub s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="P b C l 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PbCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="2 times 10 to the negative 5 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="P b I 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PbI</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="7 times 10 to the negative 9 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="P b, open parenthesis, I O 3, close parenthesis, 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Pb</mtext><mtext>(</mtext><mtext>IO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="3 times 10 to the negative 13 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>13</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>
(c) A table showing <math alttext="K sub s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> values for several lead compounds is given above. A saturated solution of which of the compounds has the greatest molar concentration of <math alttext="P b with a positive 2 charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Pb</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>? Explain. (Do not do any numerical calculations.)

skill.text: 2.F: Explain how modifications to an experimental procedure will alter results.
